div.p: Shareholders in two listed companies that deal in gas are getting restless, one year after the firms launched an ill-started process to merge.

td.p: One of the shareholders, veteran stockbroker Chandulal Shah, wants minority stakeholders to pull the plug on the proposed takeover of Carbacid Investment by BOC Kenya.
The deal fell into trouble after Alliance Nominees, associated with the family of politician Kenneth Matiba, declined to endorse the merger.

Alliance holds a 22 per cent stake in Carbacid. While Capital Markets Authority Tribunal ruled in favour of a hook-up, regulator CMA resorted to High Court seeking relief over the deal. The matter is still pending, occasioning great loss to shareholders, according to Mr Shah.

"BOC should withdraw from the process and start afresh," he said yesterday at Nation Centre, Nairobi. Mr Shah, a financial consultant - who founded suspended brokerage Shah Munge & Partners, but withdrew years before it got into trouble - has written to Specialist Corporate Consultants seeking the release of shares jointly held with his wife, Shantaben.

The letter tells the BOC registrars: "As you are aware, your holding our shares is greatly inconveniencing us and other shareholders of Carbacid Investment. Since the shares were lodged with you, we have been unable to trade in our shares."

He hopes other shareholders will emulate his action and force the companies to halt the process. The court process is likely to be painfully slow, he says, and further inconvenience shareholders, especially those who only invested in Carbacid. Mr Shah is one of the most prominent portfolio investors in Kenya, with a stake in many listed companies.

In Carbacid, he and his wife own 6,500 shares and another 1,000 in BOC. He is quick to point out that he is in favour of the process endorsed by most shareholders, but none had anticipated it "would take for ever before materialising". He further notes that Carbacid's performance has been improving, a fact that should favour a fresh process.

"Comparatively, other share prices in the Nairobi Stock Exchange have since doubled or tripled their prices. We, shareholders of Carbacid, have really lost a lot and we want to be set free from this situation," the letter copied to CMA chief executive, directors of the two companies and NSE says in part.
It is dated August 24. The NSE has in the last five years boomed with some shares going up by a factor of 10.
